5:
Let's see... "Adventurers should make it 
their policy to check all equipment 
thoroughly before embarking on 
a quest."
9: Hello, Jake. What are you doing?
12: Just writing. It's a hobby of mine.
17:
I didn't know you write. You're such 
a stickler for the rules, it's weird to 
picture you with an artistic hobby.
19: I'll admit it's a new hobby and, well...
20:
I'm writing a rulebook of sorts. 
A guidebook—for adventurers.
27:
Yes, I plan to outline the unspoken 
rules of adventuring, like what 
emergency supplies to bring and how 
to correctly submit a completed 
quest.
33:
That's my hope. I'd like it to be 
informational to both new and old 
adventurers.
37:
Knowing how thorough you are, I'm 
sure it will be!
40: I'd like to read it when you finish.
44:
Hmm, in that case, would you two 
mind being my beta readers? I'd like to 
test some of the guidelines out in the 
field.
49:
All right, let's say you encountered a 
monster. What are you supposed to 
do?
54:
Very good. When you "SEE" a monster, 
you need to identify it, assess its 
weaknesses, and act accordingly.
58:
For example, these monsters are agile, 
and often attack from above or 
behind. Let's move to the wall so they 
can only face us head-on.
62:
We also know from the chapter on 
monsters that they have sensitive 
ears.
66:
Loud noises are generally enough to 
scare them off. By following the "SEE" 
rule, we managed to avoid a fight 
entirely.
67:
However, not all fights can be avoided. 
In that case, it's important to remain 
calm and watch your opponent to 
predict their actions—and respond 
safely.
71:
Yeah, you should always be alert in the 
Kaleidoscope, huh?
74:
Exactly. But, well, you already knew 
that. I hope it'll make sense to aspiring 
adventurers. It's easier to explain 
verbally than in writing.
79:
What's the key point you want to 
teach them?
83:
I suppose... the importance of the 
Kaleidoscope's unspoken rules.
87:
People think since there's no penalty, 
they don't have to follow the rules, 
but... they're meant as guidelines to 
keep people safe. I want to explain 
WHY they matter.
89:
I know it sounds rigid, but I do hope it'll 
be an enjoyable read.
94:
I think it will. Matter-of-fact, but 
helpful—just like you!
98:
Why not interview Alk or Light? 
Interviews would add variety to the 
writing, and they are experienced 
adventurers.
102:
Huh? Light, maybe, but I'm not THAT 
knowledgeable.
107:
No, Stella's right. I would appreciate 
any insight you have regarding 
rations.
113:
Oh! Yeah, I could give you some tips 
on how to pack light, but nourishing 
meals.
117:
Get your copy of "Rules of the 
Kaleidoscope!" Get your copy now, 
before they're gone!
119:
The "Rules of the Kaleidoscope?" 
What's it about?
121:
It's a guidebook. Supposed to be good. 
*flip* This WOULD make it a lot easier 
to train rookies.
122:
Ooh, look! That recipe looks good—and 
simple! I'll have to try it when I get 
home.
125:
Looks like your book is a huge success. 
I barely managed to find a copy 
myself.
129:
Thank you. I'm proud of how it came 
out. Publishing it through the Guild 
certainly paid off—I wasn't expecting it 
to be such a hit.
133:
Guild advertising can only do so much
—the book itself is getting great 
reviews from adventurers.
138:
Yeah, you've got our seal of approval 
too, of course!
142:
We're proud of how the book came out 
too.
147:
I can think of a few people I'd like to 
recommend it to already. With this 
guidebook, they'd be prepared for 
anything.
155:
The Kaleidoscope is always shifting 
and changing—that's why it's called 
the "Kaleidoscope." I'll need to 
periodically update the rules 
accordingly.
159: You're planning to write another book?
163:
Yes, as long as adventurers are 
exploring the Kaleidoscope, I'd like to 
provide them information and 
guidelines for success.
165: Would you be willing to help me?
174:
Thank you. 
...I'm glad I met you all.
